articles.title: 'Perfect storm': Fire ban issued as South East Queensland braces for high temperatures
articles.author: Dean Miller
articles.summary: Brisbane is bracing for a perfect storm for bushfires this week. The city is preparing for temperatures in the mid to high 30s. Joel Gordon is the Assistant Chief Officer of the Rural Fire Service Queensland. Dean Miller and Joel Gordon are on 4BC Breakfast.

articles.title: Fantastic weather continues in SE Wisconsin
articles.author: Mark Baden
articles.summary: Sunshine and warm temperatures are making a run at record highs on SE Wisconsin, which is unusual for this time of the year, but it's not unusual for the summer in this part of the U.S. as well.    .

articles.title: South Carolina Homeowners Pay Some of the Lowest Insurance Costs In The Country, Despite Being In Extreme Weather Crosshairs
articles.author: The Realtor.com Team
articles.summary: South Carolina homeowners pay some of the lowest average insurance costs in the Southeast. The state has significant hurricane and flood exposure. Miami homeowners top the nation with average premiums of $22,718 annually, or 3.7% of home value. Charleston–North Charleston metro is among the nation's most flood-exposed markets.

articles.title: Spring snow hits South Island as Antarctic blast brings freezing temps, strong winds
articles.author: David Williams
articles.summary: Two southern highways are closed this morning due to snowfalling in the South Island. A wintry blast from Antarctica is expected to bring freezing temperatures, strong winds and rain to New Zealand. Southland experienced freezing temperatures overnight and experienced snowfall this morning.

articles.title: Rhode Island Homeowners Pay Mid-Range Insurance Costs In The Country
articles.author: The Realtor.com Team
articles.summary: Rhode Island homeowners pay high premiums for homeowners insurance. The state's coastal exposure and smaller housing market make it more expensive than some New England neighbors. Miami homeowners pay the highest premiums in the U.S., while those in Cape Coral and Tampa are among the most expensive.

articles.title: Tracking the Tropics: Maryland beaches at risk for rip currents amid tropical activity
articles.author: Ava Marie
articles.summary: Maryland and Delaware beaches are at risk for rip currents as two hurricanes move up the coast near Bermuda. There is also a threat for tidal flooding along the Chesapeake Bay as a result of the hurricanes and rip currents. The two hurricanes are expected to make landfall near Bermuda soon.

articles.title: Lasers provide some bird flu protection for turkey producers in Minnesota
articles.summary: Migrating birds are a threat to turkey farmers. In Minnesota, some farmers are using lasers to scare away the birds.    - NPR, KNKX Public Radio and Jazz24.  - Jazz24   – NPR, Jazz 24.

articles.title: DCS announces Remote Learning Day on Oct. 1 for Hatteras students
articles.author: Submitted Story
articles.summary: DCS announces Remote Learning Day on Oct. 1 for Hatteras students due to continued hazardous road conditions, high waves, and ocean overwash caused by the hurricanes passing offshore. Staff members who are unable to work remotely should contact their supervisor for workday options.

articles.title: Relief for SC farmers as federal grants address Helene damage amid tariff uncertainty
articles.author: Perrin Moore
articles.summary: South Carolina will receive $38.3 million in block grants for Hurricane Helene recovery. The money will be distributed by the South Carolina Department of Agriculture. Helene destroyed over 234,000 acres of timber in South Carolina. Over 16,000 farms were affected by the storm. The production of South Carolina's soybean business was valued at $138 million in 2024. China stopped buying US soybeans in May.

articles.title: Chirag Patel Sharing His Views For Youth
articles.summary: Chirag Patel is co-founder of Surya Sangam and CEO of Alarth Green Pvt. Ltd. Chirag explains 'The Process of Climate Change' from the lens of Forest Degradation and Deforestation. Green House Gases (GHGs) are the main cause of climate change. They are CO, CH, and N₂O.

articles.title: Antarctic sea ice hits its third-lowest winter peak on record
articles.author: Issam AHMED AFP
articles.summary: Antarctica's winter sea ice has hit its third-lowest peak in nearly half a century of satellite monitoring. Each year during the Southern Hemisphere's winter, the ocean around Antarctica freezes hundreds of miles beyond the continent. The maximum reach is usually observed in September or October.

articles.title: Antarctic sea ice hits its third-lowest winter peak on record
articles.author: Issam AHMED AFP
articles.summary: Antarctica's winter sea ice has hit its third-lowest peak in nearly half a century of satellite monitoring. Each year during the Southern Hemisphere's winter, the ocean around Antarctica freezes hundreds of miles beyond the continent. The maximum reach is usually observed in September or October.

articles.title: Antarctic sea ice hits its third-lowest winter peak on record
articles.author: Issam Ahmed Afp
articles.summary: Ice floating on the surface of the sea in the western Antarctic peninsula in 2016 was photographed by EITAN ABRAMOVICH. It was originally published on docafp.com, part of the BLOX Digital Content Exchange, and is available on the Internet Archive.

articles.title: Antarctic sea ice hits its third-lowest winter peak on record
articles.author: Issam Ahmed Afp
articles.summary: Ice floating on the surface of the sea in the western Antarctic peninsula in 2016. EITAN ABRAMOVICH is a kamikamist from the Antarctic Peninsula. He is also known as Amikam kAmu. He has a sonar device.

articles.title: Antarctic sea ice hits its third-lowest winter peak in the 47-year record
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Antarctica's winter sea ice has hit its third-lowest peak in nearly half a century of satellite monitoring. It highlights the growing influence of climate change on the planet's southern pole. The ocean around Antarctica freezes hundreds of kilometres beyond the continent during the Southern Hemisphere's winter.

articles.title: Why Trump Wants to Revive the Coal Industry
articles.author: New York Times
articles.summary: The burning of coal is the largest contributor to climate change worldwide. The Trump administration sees United States coal as crucial for the future of the nation's economy and the environment.       .   "The Trump administration considers the use of coal as a source of energy for the next few years.

articles.title: Wild blueberry crop in Maritimes has taken a hit from prolonged drought
articles.author: The Canadian Press
articles.summary: This summer's prolonged drought has had a costly impact on wild blueberry growers in New Brunswick and Nova Scotia. The total yield was 70 per cent less than the previous three-year average. Some farmers are now thinking about selling their land. Wild Blueberry Producers Association of Nova Scotia says the hot, dry weather is being blamed for reducing yields by 55 per cent.

articles.title: Europe defenseless against climate change
articles.author: Giorgos Lialios
articles.summary: Environmental degradation threatens the European way of life, according to a European Environment Agency report released Monday. Water scarcity affects 34% of Europeans, with agriculture identified as the most serious threat to ecosystem health. For Greece, the report acknowledges progress in coal phase-out and renewable energy. However, Greece remains vulnerable to climate-related threats including heatwaves, droughts, floods and fires.

articles.title: Antarctic sea ice hits its third-lowest winter peak on record
articles.author: France 24
articles.summary: This year's maximum of Antarctic sea ice reached 17.81 million square kilometers (6.88 million square miles) on September 17th. The 2025 maximum is the third lowest in the 47-year record, behind the all-time low in 2023 and the second-lowest in 2024.

articles.title: When floods hit the economy
articles.author: Mujeeb Ali
articles.summary: This year's monsoon rains and floods have devastated Punjab as well as other provinces. At least 842 people have lost their lives, 1.2 million people displaced and more than 4 million affected nationwide, with economic damages estimated at $6-10 billion. Pakistan contributes less than 1% to global CO₂ emissions but is among the most severely affected by climate change. The 2010 floods claimed 1,700 lives, displaced 33 million people, and caused devastation worth $40 billion nationwide. The 2022 floods caused $30 billion worth of economic losses and required $16.3 billion for reconstruction.

articles.title: Smith defends not increasing Alberta's minimum wage, set to be lowest in Canada
articles.author: The Canadian Press
articles.summary: Frost Advisory from TUE 3:39 PM EDT until WED 10:00 AM EDT. Alberta Premier Danielle Smith addresses the Global Business Forum in Banff, Alta., on Thursday, Sept. 25, 2025. JMC flag wire is true flag sponsored.

articles.title: German Embassy Hosts Climate Talk in Mogadishu Focusing on the Nexus of Climate, Peace and Security
articles.author: Staff Reporter
articles.summary: The Embassy of Germany in Nairobi organised a high-level Climate Talk in Mogadishu focusing on the links between climate change, peace and security in Somalia. The event brought together government officials, community representatives, peacebuilders and international partners to explore how environmental action can contribute to peacebuilding. The Berghof Foundation acted as Germany's implementing partner for the event.

articles.title: The Irish Times view on storm preparation: weather won't wait
articles.summary: Storm Éowyn hit Ireland in January. More than 768,000 homes lost power, 200,000 were cut off from water, and over a million lost broadband or telephone service. The Climate Change Advisory Council (CCAC) warns that the State remains unprepared as another storm season looms. CCAC calls for regional emergency hubs, pre-stocked with equipment and supplies.

articles.title: Quarry promises jobs, but the ACT fears fire risk and traffic
articles.author: Steve Evans
articles.summary: "The construction and ongoing maintenance of the access road and its verge from the Monaro Highway to the Quarry site will increase the risk of ignition and potentially spread fire to the ACT. The modification of the existing vegetation and arrangement of fuels has the potential to increase the fire risk to both environmental and built assets on the ACT side of the border."

articles.title: As hurricanes pass offshore, more Buxton homes collapse into the sea
articles.author: Wral Staff
articles.summary: Beachfront homes on Hatteras Island collapsed on Tuesday into the Atlantic Ocean. Highway 12 on the north end of Ocracoke Island was closed due to high wnids and overwash. Dare County Manager Bobby Outten said the county has more than 100 miles of shoreline. Rodanthe has become the focal point in the national conversation about the impacts of climate change.

articles.title: Cyclone behavior changing over North Indian Ocean, warns expert
articles.author: Sarfaraz Ahmed
articles.summary: Climate change is changing the behavior and intensity of tropical cyclones over the North Indian Ocean. Dr Rizwan Ahmed warned at a workshop on the Importance of Climate Literacy on World Ozone Day. The workshop was jointly organized by the Foundation for Education and Research in Climate Change and the Department of Environmental Science, Sevadal Mahila Mahavidyalaya, Nagpur.

articles.title: How Humans Transformed Animal Communities Over 50,000 Years
articles.author: Nisha Zahid
articles.summary: Fossil research shows that humans have reshaped animal communities as extensively as the great extinctions of the Ice Age. The spread of farming and livestock scrambled natural ecosystems and left a lasting mark on wildlife across the globe. The study examined fossil records spanning 50,000 years on six continents. Only 12 domesticated species appeared in nearly half of the global sites studied.

articles.title: Design contest winner sees Carlton Indigenous Day as part of Truth and Reconciliation
articles.author: Michael Oleksyn
articles.summary: Frost Advisory from TUE 3:39 PM EDT until WED 10:00 AM EDT. Carlton Comprehensive High School Grade 12 student Isabella Peters poses with the shirt with her winning design in the 2025 Carlton Indigenous Day design contest. flag wire: true flag sponsored: false article_type: pubinfo.section: cms.custom.site.

articles.title: Climate Change - 8 Counter Arguments to Debate Its Claims
articles.author: Editor
articles.summary: Climate change is a scam, manufactured by those in high places to gain power and profit for global control, using the fake narrative, carbon-based climate change as an excuse. There is no climate change emergency. The IPCC's computer-generated models based on Earth's grids are hugely flawed. The fight against it is futile and counterproductive.

articles.title: The Climate Is Changing, So Must Ghana
articles.author: Gideon Adjei-Mawutor
articles.summary: Ghana is on the frontline of climate change. Predictions point to an overall 2.9°C temperature increase in sub-Saharan Africa by 2030. The climate crisis disrupts rainfall, producing cycles of droughts and floods. Food insecurity already affects 3.6 million Ghanaians, and climate shocks will push at least one million more into poverty by 2050.

articles.title: UN expert warns Australia over defence ties with Israel
articles.author: Farid Farid
articles.summary: Australia needs to sever defence agreements with Israel or risk complicity in genocide, a United Nations expert says. Australia needs to cut ties with Israel, the expert adds. Australia has a defence agreement with Israel. Australia is a member of the United Nations Security Council.

articles.title: Portland lifts citywide burn ban
articles.author: Shane Dixon Kavanaugh
articles.summary: The city's Fire Marshal had issued a burn ban on June 23 due to high temperatures and limited rainfall. The ban was lifted Tuesday. The next few days are forecasted to be warm, with lows in the low 50s and highs in the upper 60s.

articles.title: Are you prepared for an emergency?
articles.author: Michael Hagerty
articles.summary: Harris County's Homeland Security and Emergency Management Coordinator, Mark Sloan, says flooding is one of the biggest threats to the community. He recommends putting together an emergency plan and having a stock of supplies, food, and water that can last for at least 3-5 days.

articles.title: Lasers provide some bird flu protection for turkey producers in Minnesota
articles.summary: Migrating birds are a threat to turkey farmers. In Minnesota, some are using lasers to scare them away, as they pose a risk of bird flu to the farmers. The lasers are being used by 2025 Public Media in Minnesota.  .

articles.title: Lasers provide some bird flu protection for turkey producers in Minnesota
articles.summary: Migrating birds are a threat to turkey farmers. In Minnesota, some farmers are using lasers to scare them away. WDIY's executive director Margaret McConnell updates the station's Facebook, Twitter and LinkedIn profiles about the situation. The station is a project of 2025 NPR.

articles.title: The ‘Silent Majority' Who Care About the Climate Crisis
articles.author: Who What Why
articles.summary: Up to 89 percent of the world's population wants to see climate action. Many would contribute 1 percent of their income to make that happen. People underestimate their peers' desire for change, according to researchers. Members of this 'silent majority' come from all walks of life.

articles.title: Typhoon Bualoi's Devastating Impact on Vietnam: A Tragic Search for the Missing
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Typhoon Bualoi continues to unleash destruction across Vietnam, causing catastrophic flooding and landslides. The death toll has risen to at least 26, with 22 people still unaccounted for. The relentless rain has triggered flash floods and cut off communities in Son La, Lao Cai, and Nghe An provinces.

articles.title: Depression Forming in Bay of Bengal – South Odisha, North Andhra on Alert for Oct 3
articles.author: Yajati Rout
articles.summary: A low-pressure area has emerged over the Westcentral Bay of Bengal at 5.30 pm on Tuesday. The system is expected to move northwestwards, gaining strength rapidly. It is projected to cross the south Odisha-North Andhra Pradesh coasts around the morning of October 3, posing risks to fishermen and shipping.

articles.title: Millions of birds have already migrated south for winter. What to know about fall migration in Wisconsin.
articles.author: Maia Pandey
articles.summary: Migration season in Wisconsin is in full swing. BirdCast's historical data indicates migration in Wisconsin will peak in late October, with migration numbers leveling off by early November. Migrating birds face hazards including limited food, habitat loss, and artificial lights. Amateur birders can report and track daily bird sightings on the following sites:

articles.title: Disasters and Crises in the Caribbean Region: A Review of Experiences in Seven Islands
articles.author: Now Grenada
articles.summary: The Media Institute of the Caribbean (MIC) announces the publication of 'Disasters and Crises in the Caribbean Region: A Review of Experiences in Seven Islands'. This pioneering report, supported by UNESCO, provides an in-depth review of disaster experiences in the context of communication and information across Antigua and Barbuda, Barbados, Dominica, Grenada, Guyana, Trinidad and Tobago, and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines. The report highlights the regional imperative for stronger communication.

articles.title: Chhattisgarh's Alarming Rankings in Accidental Deaths and Suicides: NCRB 2023 Report
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Chhattisgarh ranked third in accidental deaths and fourth in suicides among Indian states for the year 2023. The state recorded an alarming 16,011 accidental fatalities, trailing only Maharashtra and Haryana. Lightning accounted for 180 of the 230 deaths due to natural forces in Chhattisagarh. The suicide rate in the state decreased by 6.8% compared to 2022.

articles.title: LETTER: Trump administration ignoring scientific facts
articles.summary: The Trump administration is working to strip climate change curtailment protections because they think it's a hoax. Trump stated at the recent United Nations General Assembly it's 'the greatest con job ever perpetrated on the world' and "the 'carbon footprint' is a hoax made up by people with evil intentions."

articles.title: Uganda risks 3.1% GDP loss by 2050 without climate adaptation, World Bank warns
articles.author: Ecofin Agency
articles.summary: Uganda needs $28 billion for climate change adaptation by 2030. Agriculture accounts for 24% of GDP and 72% of the labor force in Uganda. Without action, losses on export crops alone could reach $1.5 billion. Severe climate scenarios could push more than 600,000 people into poverty and displace nearly 12 million Ugandans internally.

articles.title: Climate change forces reassessment
articles.author: John Lewis
articles.summary: Warming seas and climate are interfering with the long-standing method used to monitor the El Nino-Southern Oscillation (Enso), one of our main climate drivers. Earth Sciences New Zealand is changing the way it calculates the sea surface temperature anomalies that help it track and forecast Enso.

articles.title: Donald Trump: Putin Called US 'Hottest Country in the World'
articles.author: Pavel Morozov
articles.summary: Donald Trump met with Vladimir Putin in Alaska. Putin called the US 'the hottest country in the world' during the meeting. Trump is disappointed with Putin over the Ukraine crisis. Trump decided to tone down some of his harsher comments about Russia, promising not to use the term 'paper tiger' in future references to Putin.

articles.title: Fighting Climate Change with Youth-Led Green Enterprises in Coastal Bangladesh (UNDP - United Nations Development Programme Bangladesh)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: In Bangladesh's coastal belt, climate change is a daily reality. Rising sea levels, salinity intrusion, and recurring cyclones are eroding farmlands, destroying crops, and disrupting livelihoods. Starting spirulina farming was not easy, the culture was expensive and support was limited, but he knew it could change lives in his community.

articles.title: Guardian Essential poll: Australians back emissions target while One Nation support doubles
articles.author: Dan Jervis-Bardy
articles.summary: Fewer than a third of voters believe the country is likely to achieve the new target of cutting greenhouse gas emissions between 62% and 70% from 2005 levels. One Nation's primary vote has doubled to 13% since the May federal election, putting support for the hard-right party above the Greens. The federal government faced criticism from across the political spectrum after unveiling the 2035 emissions reduction target.

articles.title: The ‘Silent Majority' Who Care About the Climate Crisis
articles.author: Danielle Renwick
articles.summary: According to studies, between 80 and 89 percent of the world's population wants to see climate action. The Guardian asked readers to explain why they care about the climate crisis and what actions need to be made. Michael Robert Jackson, a doctor, considers climate change the most pressing health issue we face. He believes the only way to achieve change is to protest.

articles.title: European greenfinch pictured in garden in King's Lynn
articles.author: Shaun Webbley
articles.summary: Sam Owen photographed a European greenfinch in her garden last weekend. The population of greenfinches declined in the 1970s and 1980s, but increased in the 1990s. The RSPB has listed them as a red-listed bird of conservation concern.

articles.title: As Amazon's 'flying rivers' weaken with tree loss, scientists warn of worsening droughts
articles.author: STEVEN GRATTAN
articles.summary: Droughts have withered crops in Peru, fires have scorched the Amazon and hydroelectric dams in Ecuador have struggled to keep the lights on. Scientists say the cause may lie high above the rainforest, where invisible ''flying rivers'' carry rain from the Atlantic Ocean across South America. New analysis warns that deforestation is disrupting that water flow. Continued tree loss could worsen droughts in the southwestern Amazon and trigger a shift from rainforest to grassland.

articles.title: One dead, thousands displaced as torrential rains flood Les Cayes
articles.author: Class
articles.summary: Torrential rains have caused flooding in Les Cayes, Port-Salut, Cavaillon, Torbeck, Camp-Perrin and Torbeck. A man died in Maniche and Clercinie Pierre was swept away while trying to cross a river after leaving the Dory local market. More than 40,000 families have been affected by ongoing heavy rainfall from Sept. 25 to Sept. 28. Floodwaters damaged nearly 5,500 homes, about 5,000 of them in Camp Perrin alone, and inundated around 5,100 more. Access to health facilities has been severely disrupted.

articles.title: As Amazon's 'flying rivers' weaken with tree loss, scientists warn of worsening droughts
articles.author: Houston Chronicle
articles.summary: Scientists warn that 'flying rivers' that carry rain from the Atlantic Ocean westward across the Amazon are weakening due to deforestation and climate change advance.       .   "Flying rivers" are invisible streams of moisture carrying rain from Atlantic Ocean to Amazon.

articles.title: British woman moves to Australia after British weather 'made her skin burn'
articles.author: Christopher Sharp
articles.summary: Rosie Daniels, 25, has lived with plaque psoriasis since she was 10-years-old. She moved to Australia in January 2024 with her partner Harry Wilde, 28, because the British weather made her skin burn. She continues to suffer from the condition, but the milder climate has helped her manage it better.

articles.title: So about that rebounding ice
articles.author: John Robson
articles.summary: There was a kerfuffle at the start of 2024 when Tony Heller reported that Arctic sea ice on Jan. 9, 2024 had hit its highest level on that date in 20 years and suggested that it was 'rebounding'. Some people tried to argue that it didn't mean it wasn't vanishing.

articles.title: Sea Ice Loss Drives Arctic Winter Warming
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: In a new study, researchers found a correlation between declining sea ice concentration and the dramatic rise in winter temperatures in the Arctic. The Arctic region is experiencing a warming trend that is outpacing other parts of the world. The authors advocate for enhanced global cooperation in climate research and policy-making.

articles.title: Red-listed bird spotted in garden
articles.author: Shaun Webbley
articles.summary: Sam Owen photographed a greenfinch in her garden in King's Lynn last weekend. The bird is a red-listed bird of conservation concern as its population declined in the 1970s and 1980s. The recent fall in numbers has been linked to trichomonosis, a parasite-induced disease.

articles.title: Surge of Sardines: Climate Change Shapes Fisheries in Kerala
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The Central Marine Fisheries Research Institute (CMFRI) has found that climate-driven oceanographic changes are influencing the cycles of Indian oil sardine populations along Kerala's coast. Monsoon rainfall trends in 2024 led to a sudden abundance of juvenile sardines in Kerala, causing both ecological and economic impacts.

articles.title: New study shows ocean is in ‘triple planetary crisis'
articles.author: Natascha Rivera
articles.summary: The Copernicus Marine Service has released the ninth edition of its annual assessment of the condition and state of the ocean and seas. The UN has called it a 'triple planetary crisis' because of climate change, loss of biodiversity, and pollution. The ocean is heating at unprecedented levels, with spring of 2024 reaching a new record temperature: 21°C. Arctic sea ice has now reached four all-time lows between December of 2024 and March of 2025. Sea levels rose 228 millimetres between 1901 and 2024, threatening 200 million Europeans living along the coasts.

articles.title: First Alert Forecast: Lighter winds with a minor boost in showers due tomorrow, drier conditions expected back on Thursday
articles.author: Guy Hagi
articles.summary: Showers may increase Wednesday and Wednesday night, followed by a shift to southeasterly winds. The southeast flow will continue through Saturday, and localized land and sea breezes may set up across much of the state. Small medium period south swells from the north and northwest will trickle in through the rest of the week.

articles.title: Opinion: The day I stopped saying fossil fuels
articles.author: Calgary Herald
articles.summary: Edmonton Sun subscribers get unlimited online access to articles from across Canada with one account. Get exclusive access to the Edmonton Sun ePaper, an electronic replica of the print edition. Support local journalists and the next generation of journalists. Daily puzzles including the New York Times Crossword. Get email updates from your favourite authors.

articles.title: As Amazon's 'flying rivers' weaken with tree loss, scientists warn of worsening droughts
articles.author: STEVEN GRATTAN
articles.summary: Droughts have hit Peru, fires have scorched the Amazon and hydroelectric dams in Ecuador. The cause may lie high above the rainforest, where invisible 'flying rivers' carry rain from the Atlantic Ocean across South America. New analysis warns that deforestation is disrupting that water flow. The analysis found that southern Peru and northern Bolivia are especially vulnerable.

articles.title: India Faces Risky Harvest as October Rainfall Surges
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: India is bracing for above-average rainfall in October. This follows a 15% rainfall surplus in September. The monsoon rains account for 70% of the rainfall needed by India's agriculture sector. More than half of the country's farmlands rely on the monsoon for water.

articles.title: Gardeners told to leave 4 'crucial' foods on bird tables in October
articles.author: Alex Evans
articles.summary: Gardeners are urged to leave four key foods on their bird tables this October to help migrating birds. September marks a change for British gardens as non-native species of birds begin their migration south for the winter. According to bird feeding experts, this change means that the types of birds you'll see in your garden will change too.

articles.title: World's big cities see 26% rise in extreme hot days: Study
articles.author: PTI
articles.summary: There are a quarter more very hot days in the world's major cities every year on average than in 1994. The number of days above 35 degrees Celsius in 43 key cities, including the 40 most populous capitals, rose by 26 per cent over the 31-year period. 2024 recorded the highest number of hot days, 1,612, 196 more than in 2019.

articles.title: 'I moved from Manchester to Australia after British weather burned my skin'
articles.author: Christopher Sharp
articles.summary: Rosie moved from Manchester to Australia with her partner Harry in January 2024. She suffers from plaque psoriasis, which causes dry skin lesions, known as plaques, which become covered in scales. The weather in the UK caused her skin to burn, crack and bleed, so she moved to Australia. The milder climate has helped her condition.

articles.title: World's big cities see 26 per cent rise in extreme hot days: Study
articles.author: Nh Digital
articles.summary: The number of days exceeding 35°C in the world's largest cities has increased by 26 per cent over the past 30 years. 2024 registered the highest number of very hot days across the selected cities. All three of the hottest years on record have occurred within the last six years.

articles.title: ‘Don't you love this?': Labor's renewables drive wedges in Australian communities
articles.summary: Paul Murray discusses Airbus Albo, Australian borders, interest rates, renewables and more on tonight's episode of Paul Murray Live on Sky News host Paul Murray. Paul Murray is the host of Sky News Live on the Sky News channel.

articles.title: Workers keep dying from heat. Data from inside their bodies shows why.
articles.author: The Washington Post
articles.summary: Nearly half of Florida farmworkers' bodies reached dangerous temperatures in one study. Short breaks pulled them back from the danger zone, but only after they had been exposed to high temperatures for a short time.       in this case, short breaks saved them from danger.

articles.title: The island where people cannot be buried
articles.summary: Climate change is affecting the Norwegian town of Longyearbyen to a disproportionate extent. The town is covered in darkness 155 days a year, so life is getting harder for the residents. In this gallery, discover the fast-warming town in the world.

articles.title: IMD Warns of Heavy Rains in Vidarbha, Oct 1–5
articles.author: Nagpur News
articles.summary: IMD has issued a weather alert for Vidarbha region, warning of heavy to very heavy rainfall between October 1 and October 5, 2025. The weather disturbance is linked to a low-pressure system developing over the Bay of Bengal. District administrations have been instructed to remain on alert and take precautionary measures.

articles.title: The world is undergoing an energy transition. How will we show up?
articles.author: RON DICKSON
articles.summary: Growing up in Eastern Montana, the permitting debate over Colstrip Units 3/4 intrigued me. Subsequently, I've come to understand the impact of burning fossil fuels on our climate. Fish-biologist Bob Gresswell's opinion piece — Do You Fish? — summarizes how climate change has negatively impacted Montana's fisheries.

articles.title: Wildfires and dried wetlands in Yorkshire due to 'extreme heat'
articles.author: Chloe Aslett
articles.summary: The Wildlife Trusts report says the UK is underprepared for changing weather patterns caused by climate change. Extreme heat has negatively impacted local natural habitats, causing wetlands and heathlands to dry out and wildfires to start at nature reserves in Sheffield and Rotherham. The government is determined to take "robust action" to prepare for the impacts of climate change, for example by building new reservoirs and reducing water leaks.

articles.title: From London to Manila, world's biggest cities face alarming rise in heatwaves
articles.author: Stuti Mishra
articles.summary: There are 26% more days over 35C in the 40 most-populous capitals now than in the 1990s. Between 1994 and 2003, these cities averaged 1,062 days of extreme heat annually. Between 2015 and 2024, there were 1,335 such days, with 2024 recording the highest tally of all – 1,612 days. The top three years for extreme heat all came in the recent past: 2024, 2023 and 2019.

articles.title: Steve Backshall questions Donald Trump's intelligence after climate change "con" claim
articles.author: Rick Fulton
articles.summary: Steve Backshall questions Donald Trump's intelligence after he called climate change the 'greatest con job ever perpetrated on the world'. The TV wildlife presenter described the comments as a 'sucker punch' for environmentalists. Trump criticised the EU for reducing its carbon footprint and claimed countries investing in renewable energy would suffer economically. Steve, 52, is bringing his Deadly Live! arena tour to Scotland in November. He has been on our screens for two decades and has hosted The Really Wild Show and since 2008 fronted Deadly 60.

articles.title: Extreme Heat Surge in Major Cities: A 26% Increase in Scorching Days
articles.author: Daniel Foster
articles.summary: Global Cities are experiencing an unprecedented rise in very hot days with temperatures above 35 degrees Celsius. In 2024, there were 1,612 such days, surpassing the previous record set in 2019 by 196 days. This is a 52% increase from 1994 to 2024. The past nine years (2015-2023) have been the warmest on record, according to NOAA.

articles.title: The Earth reflecting less and less sunlight, study reveals
articles.author: The Brunswick News
articles.summary: The Earth became darker from 2001 to 2024, meaning it reflects less light. The Earth will be darker from 2024 to 2035.    i.e. the Earth will reflect less light than it did before 2001. It will be less reflective from then to 2024.

articles.title: Monsoon Havoc in Maharashtra: Farmers' Fields Under Water
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: In Maharashtra, an estimated 1.25 to 1.50 crore acres of farmland are suffering due to excessive rainfall. Intense rainfall, particularly during the kharif season, severely damaged crucial crops like soybean and cotton, notably in central Maharashtra, Marathwada, and parts of the western region.

articles.title: Gilani seeks stronger early warning, resilience systems
articles.author: Web Desk
articles.summary: Acting President Syed Yousaf Raza Gilani has called for widening the scope of climate resilience initiatives in Pakistan. He made the remarks during a meeting with Coco Ushiyama, Representative and Country Director of the World Food Program for Pakistan, in Islamabad. Gilani underlined the urgent need for international assistance in the wake of climate-induced disasters in South Punjab and Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa.

articles.title: Climate change mitigation should start locally
articles.author: Jessica Iloakasia
articles.summary: Stakeholders have called for grassroots-focused action to mitigate the severe impacts of climate change. They were speaking at the African Climate Caravan 2025 held in Bauchi on Tuesday. The event was organised in partnership with the Global Initiative for Food Security and Ecosystem Preservation and PARE.

articles.title: Impending Downpour: IMD Warns West Bengal of Heavy Rainfall
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The India Meteorological Department has issued a warning for West Bengal, predicting significant rainfall from Thursday onwards. The cause is a low-pressure area forming over the central Bay of Bengal, expected to develop into a depression by Thursday. This weather system is likely to bring heavy to very heavy rainfall to districts such as Howrah, South 24 Parganas and Purba Medinipur. Kolkata and other regions like Hooghly and Jhargram will also witness substantial downpours.

articles.title: Analysis: Queensland set for temperatures ‘way above' seasonal average
articles.summary: Sky News Weather Meteorologist Marina Neuman analysed Australia's weather forecast and the climbing temperatures in parts of the east coast. She found the weather forecast is not very accurate and the weather is getting warmer.    - Sky News weather forecast: "Climbing temperatures"

articles.title: Economic Watch: Industry insiders urge stronger global clean-energy cooperation
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: There is a common consensus of the international community to promote the green and low-carbon transformation against the backdrop of increasing climate change challenges around the globe. The increasing frequency of extreme weather events and deteriorating natural ecosystems pose severe threats to socio-economic development of human society.

articles.title: Season of storms on the horizon, Ireland unprepared
articles.summary: Annual review of the Climate Change Advisory Council (CCAC) criticises the Government for its lack of action in response to the storm season. CCAC urges the Government to commit to defined annual funding for climate adaptation actions starting with the Budget 2026. It also recommends the creation of emergency response hubs and a permanent extreme weather assistance scheme.

articles.title: 'I moved to Australia after British weather made my skin burn – I'll never return'
articles.author: Christopher Sharp
articles.summary: Rosie Daniels, 25, has lived with plaque psoriasis since the age of 10. She moved to Australia with her 28-year-old fiancé, Harry Wilde, in January 2024. Rosie's skin is better in Australia than in the UK because of the warmer weather and more relaxed lifestyle.

articles.title: Opinion: We need a debate on climate science and policy
articles.author: At P.M. Gmt
articles.summary: On July 29 the U.S. Department of Energy published a report on the state of climate science. On the same day the Environmental Protection Agency proposed withdrawing the 'endangerment finding' that greenhouse gases are a threat to human health and welfare. Canada has spent between $150 and $220 billion on climate change in the past 10 years.

articles.title: Opening Address at the SC-OCIS 16th Roundtable 2025 Guardians of the Earth: Climate Action Through the Lens of Maqasid Al-Shariah (Securities Commission Malaysia)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Maqasid Al-Shariah will give the opening address at the SC-OCIS 16th Roundtable 2025 Guardians of the Earth: Climate Action Through the Lens of Maqasids Al-Shariah.   For more information, visit: www.sc-ocis-roundtable.org.

articles.title: International Organisations Condemn ‘No Additional Warming' Approach As NZ Methane Target Decision Looms
articles.author: Scoop
articles.summary: No additional warming is a political trick dressed up as science, says Greenpeace Aotearoa spokesperson Amanda Larsson. Current methane emissions are fuelling the climate crisis, she says.       .   "It pretends current emissions are fine, when in reality, they're fuelling climate crisis".

articles.title: Warming Oceans Prompt Major Overhaul Of How We Monitor El Niño And La Niña
articles.author: Scoop
articles.summary: As our climate and seas warm, they're interfering with the long-standing method used to monitor the ocean component of ENSO, according to Earth Sciences NZ meteorologist Chris Brandolino. He says it's a problem for the monitoring of the ocean.

articles.title: Michigan expected to see heavy bird traffic tonight, Sept. 29. See the migration map
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Millions of birds are expected to fly over the U.S. during the fall migration. You can help hummingbirds with their feeding by helping them with their wing-feedings.    .   "Hummingbirds are nature's smallest birds"

articles.title: Typhoon Bualoi Ravages Northern Vietnam: A Tale of Devastation
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Typhoon Bualoi hit Vietnam's northern regions, unleashing torrential rains and severe flooding that brought life to a standstill in the capital, Hanoi, and surrounding areas. The natural disaster left 26 people dead, 22 missing, and heightened concerns over landslides as heavy rains surpassed 300 mm.

articles.title: Australia's central bank holds rates steady, cautious on inflation
articles.author: MARKET
articles.summary: Ibis bird perches next to the Reserve Bank of Australia headquarters in central Sydney, Australia February 6, 2018. The bird is a species of ibis, which is native to Australia and has a large number of breeding pairs. The bank's headquarters is located next to it.

articles.title: New report ranks states on climate-related health risks, clean energy policies • Ohio Capital Journal
articles.author: Nada Hassanein
articles.summary: Vermont, New York, Washington, New Jersey and Maine have the best combination of relatively low environmental risks and robust environmental policies. West Virginia, Kentucky, Louisiana, Florida and Mississippi ranked lowest on the 50-state scorecard produced by the Commonwealth Fund. Nevada, New Mexico and Arizona faced the greatest extreme heat-driven health risks. Alaska and Hawaii ranked highest in air quality.

articles.title: Commission Report Warns: Ocean Health in Crisis
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Every part of the ocean is under threat from climate change, biodiversity loss and pollution, according to the Copernicus report. The annual report provides data on how changes in the ocean affect ecosystems, food security, economies, coastal communities and global climate regulation. The EU is stepping up action by providing trusted data to monitor the ocean's health and to support measures that protect biodiversity, cut pollution and strengthen resilience against climate change.

articles.title: Copernicus Report: Oceans Continue to Heat Up
articles.summary: Global ocean surface temperatures reached a record 21 degrees in the spring of 2024, according to Copernicus Marine Service's ninth Ocean State Report. Even seemingly small changes in the ocean surface temperature could have enormous effects on important components of the Earth system, they say.

articles.title: No tangible action taken by government ahead of storm season, climate advisory warns
articles.author: David MacRedmond
articles.summary: The Climate Change Advisory Council has called on the government to take action to mitigate the impacts of powerful storms like those seen last winter. Storms Darragh and Éowyn left hundreds of thousands of homes and businesses without power. The Council wants to see the establishment of 'Emergency Response Hubs', sites where people can go for necessities in the event of losing power or their homes being flooded, and a permanent establishment of an 'Extreme Weather Assistance Scheme' to support people, businesses and communities.

articles.title: Photos: Typhoon Bualoi kills dozens in Vietnam and Philippines
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Typhoon Bualoi has killed dozens of people in Vietnam and the Philippines. The storm battered small islands in central Philippines last week, toppling trees and power pylons, unleashing floods and forcing 400,000 people to evacuate. In Vietnam, 13 people were killed, while a search is ongoing for 20 others. At least 800 homes were flooded and nearly 6,000 hectares of crops were inundated.

articles.title: Typhoon Bualoi becomes Vietnam's deadliest storm this year
articles.author: Stuti Mishra
articles.summary: Typhoon Bualoi has caused 19 deaths and left 21 people missing in central Vietnam. It is the country's deadliest storm this year. It damaged over 100,000 homes, injured 88 people and evacuated over 28,500 people. Power cuts affected over 347,000 households and thousands of hectares of crops were inundated. Forecasters warned of continued heavy rain, flash floods, and landslides.

articles.title: 'Brakes slammed': Global emissions growth has slowed drastically in decade since Paris Agreement
articles.author: Chris Brayford
articles.summary: Growth in global carbon emissions has slowed to 0.32% a year in the decade since the Paris Agreement was signed in late 2015, according to a new analysis from the Energy and Climate Analysis Centre.       .   ...

articles.title: Mallorca Storm: Rain & Warnings East
articles.summary: Orange alerts have been issued across Valencia, Alicante, Murcia, and the Balearic Islands this Tuesday. There is a growing pattern of more frequent and intense precipitation in these regions due to climate change. The Mediterranean basin is particularly vulnerable due to its geographical location and sensitivity to climate shifts. Climate models predict a continued increase in extreme precipitation events across the Iberian Peninsula and Baleari Islands.

articles.title: Westmorland and Furness in top 10 most polluted areas in England
articles.author: Imogen Barber
articles.summary: Westmorland and Furness came in at number ten on the list, with 11.5 tonnes of greenhouse gas emissions per capita. Greenhouse gas emissions are linked to global warming and climate change. They can also worsen human health by contributing to air pollution, which can lead to more respiratory and cardiovascular diseases, infectious diseases, mental health problems, and premature deaths.

articles.title: Duck survey planned for Oct. 11 in Jackson County
articles.author: Telegraph Herald
articles.summary: Jackson County Conservation and Dubuque County Conservation will jointly host a bird survey event this fall. The event will be held beginning at 5:30 p.m. Oct. 11 at Green Island Lake, 51576 Green Island Road near Miles, Iowa.

articles.title: CCAC: Not enough action taken after previous storm fallout
articles.author: Stella Meehan
articles.summary: The Climate Change Advisory Council (CCAC) has launched its 'Annual Review on Preparing for Ireland's Changing Climate' today (Tuesday, 30 September). It is disappointed that a cross-government review of the response to Storm Éowyn, expected to identify key learnings, is overdue and remains unpublished. The CCAC has urged the government to take action on the delivery of the 'Emergency Response Hubs' which assist people with basic needs in the event of services outages. It also wants to see the permanent establishment of a resourced Extreme Weather Assistance Scheme to support people, businesses and communities. Prof. Peter Thorne, chair of the CCAC Adaptation Committee,

articles.title: Murujuga rock art safeguards weakened despite gas hub's harms
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: Emissions curbs loosened on a major gas plant harming nearby ancient rock art in Western Australia's Pilbara region. Woodside warned the curbs amounted to an 'effective refusal' of the project. Environment Minister Murray Watt agreed industrial emissions from the resources giant's gas plant were harming the World Heritage-listed rock art.

articles.title: Antarctica Temps Soar 35°C: Impact on Australia?
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Sudden stratospheric warming is taking place in the atmosphere above Antarctica. It's caused by an unexpected warming of the stratosphere 12 to 40 km above the ground. This month, three pulses of heat pushed temperatures up by 25°C or more. Sudden large-scale warming was thought to be rare in the Southern Hemisphere, but it's more common than expected in the Northern Hemisphere. It has flow-on effects for the weather in Australia.

articles.title: Vietnam Struggles with Devastating Floods and Landslides
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Typhoon has caused flooding and landslides in Vietnam, killing 19 people. Several people, including fishermen, are missing. The weather agency reports heavy rains exceeding 30 cm in parts of the country in the past 24 hours. Many northern and central provinces are grappling with overflowing rivers and blocked roads. In Hanoi, authorities issued warnings as the Red River is rising.

articles.title: Nigeria: Fresh Flood Alert Issued to 18 States
articles.author: Bidon Mibzar
articles.summary: The Federal Ministry of Environment has issued flood alerts to Delta, Kogi, Bayelsa, and 15 other states. The red alert list includes Zamfara, Lagos, Kaduna, Kebbi, Kano, Taraba, Enugu, Katsina, Abia, Borno, and Akwa Ibom.

articles.title: Flood fix
articles.summary: Carol Archer is urging Jamaica to adopt the 'sponge city' model to cope with climate change and urban flooding. Her recommendation comes in the wake of two consecutive weekends of heavy rainfall in the Corporate Area, which caused widespread and repeated flooding in several areas. According to Archer, Jamaica's infrastructure and urban planning strategies have not kept pace with modern development.

articles.title: Ireland unprepared for another Storm Éowyn as season of extreme weather looms
articles.author: Caroline O'Doherty
articles.summary: The Climate Change Advisory Council (CCAC) criticises the delay in the review of the Storm Éowyn response. CCAC's comments come in its annual review of Ireland's climate adaptation capacity. It urges immediate action to ensure readiness for a repeat of the storm.

articles.title: Eastline's "The Hours Are Feminine" Hits With Hurricane Force
articles.author: Cindi Sansone-Braff
articles.summary: EastLine Theatre presents "The Hours Are Feminine" by José Rivera in celebration of Hispanic Heritage Month. Two-act drama takes place in Ronkonkoma, a town on Long Island, a few months before John F. Kennedy became the first Catholic President of the United States. It tells the story of two families, an assimilated Italian and an immigrant Puerto Rican family, separated by cultural differences and a language barrier. The solid cast, bursting with electrifying onstage chemistry, propelled the action forward.

articles.title: MetService Weather: October 1, 2025
articles.summary: James Renwick is a climate scientist at Victoria University. He explains why we should care about climate overshoot and why it's important to take care about it. He is with us to discuss it with the audience.       .

articles.title: China's social insurance fund hits 4-year high return
articles.author: The Standard 英文虎報
articles.summary: People play cards at the entrance of an air-conditioned metro station amid a red alert for heat in Chongqing, China on July 31, 2025. The weather is expected to be hot in the metro station.    in the rest of the country.

articles.title: Warming Oceans Prompt Major Overhaul Of How We Monitor El Niño And La Niña
articles.summary: Global warming is changing the way we monitor one of the world's biggest climate drivers, El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO). Earth Sciences NZ meteorologist Chris Brandolino says as our climate and seas warm, they're interfering with the long-standing method used to monitor the ocean component of ENSO. The new approach uses a method that assesses how unusually warm or cool ocean temperatures are in specific locations.

articles.title: New plan to manage and protect changing East Devon coastline
articles.author: Angelov
articles.summary: East Devon District Council and South West Flood & Coastal are preparing a Beach and Cliff Management Plan for Budleigh Salterton. The plan will address risks from coastal erosion, cliff falls, flooding and climate change while taking into account the town's landscape and environmental value. Community involvement will be a key part of the project, with five rounds of engagement planned. The first round will focus on raising awareness and gathering local knowledge.

articles.title: The depth of climate knowledge
articles.author: Anthony J. Sadar
articles.summary: Climate Week NYC wrapped up last week. Anthony Sadar is a professor of science at Geneva College, an adjunct professor of meteorology at Beaver Falls, PA, and a Certified Certified Meteorologist. He believes that climate change is complex and nuanced and needs to be understood in three dimensions.

articles.title: Las quejas por los recortes educativos se extienden por toda la Costa da Morte
articles.author: Toni Longueira
articles.summary: Sudden stratospheric warming is taking place above Antarctica. It's caused by an unexpected warming of the stratosphere 12 to 40 km above ground. This month, three pulses of heat have each pushed temperatures up by 25C or more. Sudden large-scale warming was thought to be rare in the Southern Hemisphere, but it's more common in the Northern Hemisphere. It can have flow-on effects for the weather, such as drier conditions in Australia.

articles.title: How Humans Reshaped Animal World
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Fossil bones from six continents show how people have fundamentally transformed mammal communities 50,000 years of animal history. During the last Ice Age, mammal communities formed distinct patterns across continents based on natural climate zones and geographic barriers, but after farming began, just a handful of livestock species spread along with humans and scrambled those boundaries forever. The study shows how agriculture and hunting profoundly changed the make-up of natural ecosystems worldwide 10,00 years ago.

articles.title: Clive Palmer's multi-billion dollar claims make a mockery of a tribunal that allows foreign investors ...
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: The billionaire's last three cases are part of a growing global list from fossil fuel companies against government decisions to reduce carbon emissions. Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast to stay up-to-date on the latest news from Australia and the world.

articles.title: UK gardeners told to leave one common food item out for robins
articles.author: Ashley Bautista
articles.summary: Gardeners are urged to leave one type of food out for robins this autumn and winter. Robins do not migrate south for winter, so they need help all year round. Garden experts at Ark Wildlife are urging gardeners to help these classic British birds through the colder months. They advise to leave out suet pellets, fat balls, fruits and berries in winter.

articles.title: ‘New in the experience of the Earth': 12 voices on climate change explain how we got here
articles.author: Charlie Lewis
articles.summary: Australia is predicted to suffer more frequent and severe flooding, cyclones, heatwaves, droughts and bushfires. More than 1.5 million people are at risk from rising sea levels by 2050. Environment Minister Murray Watt gave Woodside approval to continue operating its North West Shelf facilities in Western Australia for another 40 years.

articles.title: Young Generation Must Care About Climate Change
articles.summary: Climate change in Pakistan has already scarred the land. The 2022 floods displaced 35 million people, many of them students. Climate change is not just an environmental issue, but a generational battle and a global emergency. Without youth-led climate action, unemployment, food insecurity, and poverty will intensify.

articles.title: New study reveals adaptation scenarios at Seacliff, New Brighton state beaches
articles.author: Santa Cruz Sentinel
articles.summary: Seacliff and New Brighton state beaches are vulnerable to climate change-fueled conditions of high waters and heavy storms in the winter of 2022-23 at Santa Cruz County's coastline.    "Climate change is real, it's now and it's everywhere"

articles.title: Taking stock of feed gaps
articles.author: Leighton Hart
articles.summary: Dairy farmers across Australia are reflecting on a tough 18 to 24 months marked by erratic weather, depleted feed reserves and soaring input costs, which has affected their business.       .   for confidential support call the Samaritans on 08457 90 90 90 or visit a local Samaritans branch or click here for details.

articles.title: New Study Sheds Light on How the Iron Age Started
articles.author: Nisha Zahid
articles.summary: Climate change played a key role in shaping how ancient communities farmed and survived at the start of the Iron Age. Ebrar Sinmez and colleagues studied archaeobotanical remains from two sites in Turkey's Amuq Valley: Tell Atchana and Toprakhisar Höyük. The team focused on two major climate shifts during the Holocene epoch: the 4.2 and 3.2 thousand years before present. These episodes left widespread marks on societies from the Indus Valley to the Mediterranean.

articles.title: Australia's glaring climate change contradiction
articles.author: Leith van Onselen
articles.summary: The Albanese government unveiled its 2035 climate targets. They promise to reduce emissions by more than 62% and up to 70% below 2005 levels. Australia emits only around 1% of the world's human-induced carbon emissions. The three biggest emitters, the USA, China and India, don't have similar binding targets.

articles.title: Climate council criticises Government for not learning lessons in storm response
articles.author: Alison O'Reilly
articles.summary: Storm Darragh and Storm Éowyn caused widespread wind damage across Ireland from December to January last year. Hundreds of thousands of homes were left without power and damage estimated in the hundreds of millions of euro. An annual review published on Tuesday by the Climate Change Advisory Council criticised the Government for its lack of action in response to the storm season. It urged the Government to commit to defined annual funding for climate adaptation actions.

articles.title: Centarl Luzon, Negros report over P87 million agricultural damage
articles.author: Gilbert Bayoran
articles.summary: Typhoons and floods caused damage to agriculture in Central Luzon and Negros Occidental. More than P87 million worth of rice crops destroyed in Nueva Ecija, Bulacan, Bataan, Tarlac, Zambales and Pampanga. 116.4 hectares of agricultural crops in 18 barangays of San Carlos City were damaged by flooding.

articles.title: Mystery green lights paint Russian skies from St. Petersburg to Siberia, photos go viral
articles.author: The Economic Times
articles.summary: The aurora borealis has been illuminating Russian skies, visible even in St. Petersburg. The green glow is caused by aurora aurora, which is visible in the northern sky. It's also visible from the southern part of the Russian mainland.

articles.title: Conservation in a hotter world
articles.author: Mongabay
articles.summary: For most of its history, conservation has been about setting aside reserves, managing fisheries and safeguarding livelihoods. Global temperatures are projected to rise by 3-5°C by the end of the century, so the future of conservation is untenable.

articles.title: Why hotter summers are bad for the UK economy
articles.author: Famagusta Gazette
articles.summary: Lotanna Emediegwu, Jubril Animashaun, Manipal Academy of Higher Education and Verónica Vienne Arancibia, University of Huddersfield are discussing the impact of climate change on the economy. They discuss drought in Africa and hurricanes in the Caribbean.

articles.title: Mozambique launches regional mechanism to restore degraded landscapes in southern Africa
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Mozambique has launched the Southern Africa Exchange Mechanism aimed at driving joint efforts to restore degraded landscapes and strengthen climate resilience across the region. The inauguration coincided with the opening of the third regional seminar of the Drylands Sustainable Landscapes Impact Program, funded by the Global Environment Facility.

articles.title: World's big cities see 26 pc rise in extreme hot days: Study
articles.author: The Siasat Daily
articles.summary: World's major cities are experiencing a quarter more very hot days every year on average than they did three decades ago, according to a new analysis published on Tuesday. Researchers at the UK-based International Institute for Environment and Development examined temperature data and found that it is getting hotter.

articles.title: 10 years after the Paris Agreement, countries are still missing climate deadlines
articles.author: Grist
articles.summary: The 2015 Paris Agreement was inked nearly a decade ago. It states that global temperature rise should be limited to well below 2 degrees Celsius over preindustrial levels. The treaty hinges on almost 200 countries periodically submitting goals, but they are insufficient to keep to the goals of the agreement.

articles.title: Amazon's 'flying rivers' weaken, scientists warn of worsening droughts
articles.author: ABC News
articles.summary: Scientists warn that 'flying rivers' are weakening as deforestation and climate change advance. Flying rivers are invisible streams of moisture that carry rain from the Atlantic Ocean westward across the Amazon, but scientists say they are getting weaker due to climate change and deforestation.

articles.title: World's big cities see 26% rise in extreme hot days: Study
articles.author: The Economic Times
articles.summary: Global cities face 26% more very hot days annually than three decades ago. 2024 will be the highest number of hot days, with 2024 marking the highest count in major global cities.    .   i   in the world's major cities will have more hot days in 2024.

articles.title: 'I moved from Manchester to Australia after British weather burned my skin'
articles.author: Manchester Evening News
articles.summary: A woman has shared how she was forced to move to Australia because her skin condition became so severe that she was left with no option but to leave the US and move halfway around the world to Australia. She had to move because of her severe skin condition.

articles.title: Northeast Pacific endures fourth-largest marine heat wave on record
articles.author: Mongabay
articles.summary: The Northeast Pacific ocean, off the U.S. West Coast is experiencing its fourth-largest marine heat wave since record-keeping began in 1982. "The extent of the current Pacific marine heatwave should be surprising, but unfortunately, record breaking heat is our new norm," says marine scientist Chris Free.

articles.title: From London to Manila, world's biggest cities face alarming rise in heatwaves
articles.author: AOL
articles.summary: Pretoria now averages 11 days above 35C every year. Johannesburg recorded only three such days in the 1990s. The impacts will be worse in low-income or unplanned communities in the Global South, according to the analysis.

articles.title: How humans reshaped the animal world (Macquarie University)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Fossil bones from six continents show how human impacts have disrupted natural mammal communities as profoundly as the Ice Age extinctions. The rise of agriculture and livestock is one of the most significant human impacts on the natural world, according to the new research. The study is published in the journal "Fossils".

articles.title: Air temperatures over Antarctica have soared 35°C above average. What does this unusual event mean ...
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: The cold air above Antarctica is up to 35°C warmer than the cold air high above Antarctica now. It's currently 35 degrees Celsius warmer than currently. It is above 35 degrees C.    in the high atmosphere above Antarctica.

articles.title: Study is first to show whether nesting heat affects sea turtle hatchling 'IQ'
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: As sand temperatures continue to rise, concerns about the future of sea turtles are growing. Hotter nests skew sex ratios, producing more females than males, and increasing the risk of sea turtle die-off in the future. It's also affecting the number of sea urchins.

articles.title: New Study Sheds Light on How the Iron Age Started
articles.author: Greek Reporter
articles.summary: Climate change played a key role in shaping how ancient communities farmed and survived at the start of the Iron Age, according to a new study led by archaeologist Ebrar Sinmez. The research was published in the Journal of Archaeological Science and is based on excavations at Alalakh.

articles.title: As Floods Worsen, Pakistan Is the Epicenter of Climate Change
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: Pakistan is the center of climate change, according to Yale E360. Pakistan is experiencing heavy flooding due to the recent monsoon rains and is vulnerable to future droughts and floods due to climate change in Pakistan.    i.e. because of global warming.
